title: Understanding Stability Analysis
text:
Thermodynamic stability can be evaluated using Gibbs free energy, denoted as G. The formula is given by:
$$G=ΔH-T$$ × ΔS
Where:
- ΔH is the enthalpy change
- ΔS is the entropy change
- T is the temperature (in Kelvin)
Try to determine which form of chlorine has a lower G value under standard conditions at $$298$$ K.

title: Remember the Units
text: Ensure consistent units when calculating Gibbs free energy:\n- Convert ΔH from $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ if needed.\n- Use the temperature in Kelvin directly.

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for Gaseous $$Cl_2$$
text:
Let's start by calculating the Gibbs free energy for $$Cl_2$$ (gas). Use the formula $$G=ΔH-T$$ × ΔS with the following values in $$ rac{J}{mol}$$:
- $$ΔH=0$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- $$S=223.08$$ $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$
- $$T=298$$ K

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for Solid $$Cl_2$$
text:
Now calculate the Gibbs free energy for $$Cl_2$$ (solid) using the formula $$G=ΔH-T$$ × ΔS with these values in $$ rac{J}{mol}$$:
- $$ΔH=-6.4$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- $$S=50.00$$ $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$
- $$T=298$$ K

title: Compare the Gibbs Free Energies
text: Compare the Gibbs free energies calculated for $$Cl_2$$ in gaseous and solid forms to determine which is more stable. The form with the lower Gibbs free energy is more stable.
